Dear Ms. Carey:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.

Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a youth
on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff pushed youth off the porch, causing injury to her left knee.
Investigation Interviews:
On 11/18/24 the agency reported that Youth A pushed Staff 1.
Staff 1 then pushed Youth A. No injuries were reported. Staff 1
was suspended pending investigation. Video of the incident was
available. A second report was filed that day by Complainant 2,
indicating Youth A’s knee was injured in the incident.
Chief Administrator was contacted via email on 11/19/24. A
request was made for video of the incident and the staff schedule
to arrange interviews. On 11/20/24 face-to-face contact occurred
with MDHHS Worker and the Chief Administrator at her office.
Chief Administrator reported Staff 1 was suspended. On 12/3/24
the video of the incident was provided to DCWL and MDHHS.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported that on the
day of the incident, she went into the bathroom and realized there
was not any toilet paper. Youth A asked Staff 1 to get more toilet
paper out of the locked supply closet. Staff 1 was on the phone
with her mother and daughter. Youth A noted that staff are not
supposed to be on personal calls while working. Youth B then told
Staff 1, “she’s talking to you”, referring to Youth A. Staff 1
answered, “I know”. Youth A then made a comment to Youth B
about getting a urinary tract infection if she had to wait too long.
Staff 1 yelled that she would get the toilet paper when she got off
the phone. Youth A yelled that she was talking to Youth B, not
Staff 1. Staff 1 became argumentative and “walked up on” Youth
A, yelling and spitting while talking. Youth A asked Staff 1 to stop
spitting at her. Staff 1 said she could yell if she wanted to and
continued screaming at Youth A. Youth B then stated that Staff 2
2

pulled into the driveway. Youth A went to the door, leaned out the
door and told Staff 2, “get your staff, I’m about to beat the s*** out
of her”. Staff 1 then walked up right against Youth A in the
doorway. Youth A pushed Staff 1 away. Staff 1 responded by
shoving Youth A out the door and off the porch, while yelling and
spitting. Youth A yelled at Staff 1 that she should never put her
hands on kids. Staff 2 then approached and got in between Youth
A and Staff 1. Everyone went back in the house and Staff 2 took
Staff 1 to the office to talk. Staff 1 then left the facility and Staff 2
spoke with Youth A. Staff 2 asked Youth A if she was hurt and
needed to go to urgent Care. Youth A declined. Youth A reported
she did not have any injuries, but her knee was somewhat sore as
she had a history of bursitis that may have been aggravated by
the fall.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B stated she was
present for the incident and heard Youth A ask Staff 1 for more
toilet paper. Youth B said she was not paying much attention, as
she was getting ready that morning. However, he heard Staff 1
and Youth A arguing. Staff 2 then pulled into the driveway and
Youth B went out to tell her what was happening. While standing
outside, before Staff 2 got out of her car, Staff 1 pushed Youth A
off the porch. Youth A landed in the grass on her knees. Youth C
was in the house at the time. Youth B stated she did not have any
prior concerns about Staff 1. However, she noted that Staff 1 did
have previous verbal altercations with Youth A.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C was present for the
incident and heard Youth A and Staff 1 arguing about toilet paper.
Youth C observed Staff 1 to be on her personal phone, talking to
her mother and daughter. Staff 1 told Youth A to wait. Youth A told
Youth B she, “didn’t have time to get a UTI”. Staff 1 then began
yelling and swearing at Youth A. Youth A yelled back. Youth C
recalled a lot of yelling, swearing, and name calling from Staff 1.
Staff 2 then pulled in the driveway. Youth A went on the porch to
intercept Staff 2. However, Staff 1 followed Youth A to the door,
and continued calling Youth A names. Youth C saw Youth A push
Staff 1 away from her. Staff 1 then pushed Youth A off the porch,
where she fell on her knees into the grass. Youth C stated she
was aware Staff 1 left after that and has been suspended since.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility office on
11/20/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated she
arrived at the facility to start her shift on 11/18/24 and observed
3

Youth A standing up from the ground, outside the front door. Staff
2 stated she did not see the incident as it apparently happened
while she was parking her car. When she approached the
building, Youth A and Staff 1 were arguing back and forth. Based
on what they were saying it seemed that Youth A and Staff 1 had
pushed each other. Staff 2 asked everyone to go inside. Staff 2
spoke with Staff 1 briefly and informed her the video would be
reviewed. Staff 1 then left the facility. Staff 2 spoke with Youth A
and asked if she needed to go to urgent care; Youth A declined.
Youth A did not report any injuries and Staff 2 did not observe any
injuries. Staff 2 then informed Chief Administrator there was an
incident. The video was reviewed, and Staff 2 saw Youth A and
Staff 1 were arguing. Staff 1 then followed Youth A to the front
door. Youth A pushed Staff 1 away. Staff 1 then pushed Youth A
off the porch. The video had audio and Staff 1 could be heard
yelling and swearing at Youth A. Staff 2 stated that Youth A was
also yelling and very escalated, but Staff 1 did not do anything to
try to deescalate the situation.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported she was on the phone with
her daughter on 11/18/24 when Youth A asked for toilet paper.
Staff 1 told Youth A to wait a minute. However, Youth A got mad
and started yelling. Staff 1 denied yelling or swearing, but stated
words were exchanged. Youth A threatened to assault Staff 1.
Staff 2 then pulled into the driveway and Youth A went to the
porch. Youth A yelled to Staff 2, “come get this b**** (Staff 1)
before I beat her a**.” Youth A was standing by the door and used
both hands to push Staff 1 in the chest. Staff 1 stated she recently
had surgery on her chest and reacted to the push with a reflex by
pushing Youth A. Youth A leaped off the porch and landed on the
ground. Youth A told Staff 2 that Staff 1 was spitting on her, which
was not true. Staff 1 and Staff 2 spoke briefly, then Staff 1 left.
Staff 1 stated that nothing physical like that had ever happened
before, although there had been verbal incidents between Youth A
and Staff 1 previously. Regarding the youth at the facility, Staff 1
said, “disrespect me and I’ll disrespect you”. Staff 1 asked what
was going to be done about Youth A pushing her. Staff 1 indicated
she felt the incident was Youth A’s fault and there should be
consequences.
Documents reviewed:
• The agency cell phone policy for staff was reviewed. The
policy allows staff to have personal cell phones while on
shift and exercise discretion in using phones for personal
4

calls. The policy stated staff are not allowed to accept and
talk on personal cell phones while in front of youth.
• Human Resources file for Staff 1- There was no disciplinary
action on file. Staff 1 completed Conflict Resolution training
on 6/11/24, Crisis Prevention, Intervention and De-
escalation on 8/21/24.
Video reviewed:
Three camera views were available: outdoor camera above the
porch, outdoor doorbell camera, and interior camera in the living
room. Audio from the outdoor cameras recorded Staff 1 inside the
facility, yelling and swearing at Youth A. Staff 1 repeatedly
shouted, “I don’t care”, “I don’t give a f*** about no job”, and “beat
me (Youth A)”, antagonizing Youth A. Youth A was heard
repeatedly telling Staff 1 “stop f***ing talking to me” and “don’t
f***ing spit on me”.
At one point Staff 1 told Youth A, “girly bye. I hope you gone
forever”. Youth A, who had a history of suicidal ideation, asked,
“why would you say that?” and requested to call her case
manager. Staff 1 refused to call the case manager.
The indoor and outdoor cameras showed Staff 1 following Youth A
from the kitchen, through the living room, to the front door. Youth
A opened the screen door and yelled toward Staff 2’s car, “(Staff
2) come get your f***ing staff before I beat the s*** out of her.”
Youth C stayed in the facility as Youth B walked toward Staff 2’s
car. Staff 2 got out of her car and as she walked around the back
of it, the physical altercation occurred between Youth A and Staff
1. Staff 1 had walked directly behind Youth A, putting Youth A
between Staff 1 and the screen door. Youth A turned around and
shoved Staff 1, stating, “get out of my f***ing face”. Staff 1
immediately stepped toward the door, pushing Youth A with two
hands, yelling, “don’t f***ing push me! What the f*** is wrong with
you?” Youth A fell off the porch, initially landing on her feet, then
falling to her knees. Staff 2 then stepped out from behind the car,
while Youth A was on the grass. Youth A and Staff 1 continued to
yell and swear at one another. Staff 2 approached and directed
everyone into the facility. Staff 1 and Youth A continued to argue.
Staff 2 directed them to stop talking to one another. Staff 1 then
left the facility.
Analysis Based on interviews and video review, a violation was found. Staff
1 followed Youth A to the front door and stood directly next to her,
while continuing to verbally antagonize Youth A. Youth A pushed
5

Staff 1 away and Staff 1 responded by pushing Youth A off the
porch.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or discriminatory
language including negative references to a youth’s background or
appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff was verbally abusive toward youth, yelling and using
derogatory language.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported that during
the incident on 11/18/24 Staff 1 yelled and argued with her. Youth
A asked Staff 1 to stop several times. Staff 1 replied that she
could yell if she wanted to.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B stated she was
present for the incident on 11/18/24 and heard Staff 1 and Youth
A arguing. Youth B noted that Staff 1 did have previous verbal
altercations with Youth A.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C was present for the
incident on 11/18/24 and heard Youth A and Staff 1 arguing. Staff
1 was yelling and swearing at Youth A. Youth A yelled back.
Youth C recalled a lot of yelling, swearing, and name calling from
Staff 1. Staff 2 then pulled in the driveway. Youth A went on the
porch to intercept Staff 2. However, Staff 1 followed Youth A to the
door, and continued calling Youth A names.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility office on
11/20/24 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated she
6

arrived at the facility to start her shift on 11/18/24 and observed
Youth A and Staff 1 were arguing back and forth. Video was later
reviewed, and Staff 1 could be heard yelling and swearing at
Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Regarding the incident on 11/18/24, Staff 1
denied yelling or swearing, but stated words were exchanged.
Staff 1 stated there had been verbal incidents between Youth A
and Staff 1 previously.
Video reviewed:
Three camera views with audio were available: outdoor camera
above the porch, outdoor doorbell camera, and interior camera in
the living room. Staff 1 was yelling at a level that her voice, while
inside the facility, was recorded on the outdoor camera. Staff 1
was observed yelling and swearing at Youth A. In addition, Staff 1
made a statement to Youth A, “girly bye. I hope you gone forever”.
Youth A, who had a history of suicidal ideation, asked, “why would
you say that?” and requested to call her case manager. Staff 1
refused to call the case manager.
Analysis Based on interviews and video review, a violation was found. Staff
1 engaged in a verbal altercation with Youth A, in which she
yelled, swore, made derogatory comments, and continuously
verbally antagonized Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff responded inappropriately to a situation by yelling, swearing,
and becoming physical with youth. Staff did not attempt to
deescalate the situation or take accountability for their actions.
Investigation Interviews:
During interviews on 11/20/24 with Youth A, Youth B, Youth C,
and Staff 2, it was reported that Staff 1 engaged in a verbal
altercation with Youth A on 11/18/24.
7

During an interview on 11/20/24 Staff 1 denied yelling or swearing
at Youth A on 11/18/24. Staff 1 admitted words were exchanged,
and there had been prior verbal altercations with Youth A. Staff 1
admitted to pushing Youth A at the door on 11/18/24, causing her
to go off the porch. Regarding the youth at the facility, Staff 1 said,
“disrespect me and I’ll disrespect you”. Staff 1 asked what was
going to be done about Youth A pushing her. Staff 1 indicated she
felt the incident was Youth A’s fault and there should be
consequences.
Video review:
Staff 1 was observed to yell, swear at, and make derogatory
comments toward Youth A. Staff 1 failed to utilize any techniques
to deescalate the situation. Youth A asked Staff 1 to stop
repeatedly. Staff 1 followed Youth A to the front door while
continuing to verbally antagonize her. Youth A pushed Staff 1
away, Staff 1 responded by pushing Youth A and continuing to yell
at her.
Analysis Based on interviews and video review, a violation was found. Staff
1 engaged in a verbal altercation with Youth A, in which she
yelled, swore at, and continuously antagonized Youth A. Staff 1
made no attempts to deescalate the situation. Staff 1 followed
Youth A to the front door and stood directly next to her, while
continuing to yell. Youth A pushed Staff 1 away and Staff 1
responded by pushing Youth A off the porch. After pushing Youth
A, Staff 1 continued to verbally escalate the situation. When
interviewed, Staff 1 took no accountability for her actions, further
demonstrating her inability to perform duties of the position.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-
Description resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 11/1/24 youth arrived home from school, there were no staff
present at the home. Youth was left outside in the rain for an hour.
8

Investigation On 11/18/24 Complainant 2 reported that Youth A arrived at the
facility after school on 11/1/24 and found that staff were not
present. The door was locked, and it was raining. Youth A and a
peer had to wait outside for an hour.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted via email on 11/19/24.
FCW reported that she was made aware of the incident by Youth
A. Youth A reported to FCW that she was outside for an hour
when she arrived home from school. There were no staff there.
Youth A and Youth B broke into a window and climbed inside to
unlock the door. Youth A told FCW that when they entered the
facility, the electricity was not on, so she called the police from a
neighbor’s house. Staff at the facility reported to FCW that the
youth were alone no longer than fifteen minutes, due to there
being an emergency that staff had to attend to with another youth.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported that she and
Youth B arrived at the facility on 11/1/24 after school and found
that staff were not there. The door was locked, and the two youth
eventually were able to climb through an unlocked window. Youth
A reported she went to a neighbor’s house to call the police as
they were there alone, and the power was out. Youth A stated
they were alone for approximately 1.5 hours, before Staff 2 arrived
at the house. Youth A stated she was unsure if the power was out
in the whole neighborhood. However, the power came back on
after Staff 2 arrived. Youth A reported she later learned that staff
was not at the house due to an emergency with another youth.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported arriving at
the facility after school on 11/1/24, to an empty house. The front
door was locked, and the agency van was gone. Youth B and
Youth A climbed in through a window and found that the power
was out. They then went to a neighbor’s house down the road and
called the police. Staff 2 arrived at the same time as the police.
Youth B reported they were alone from 2:15-3:00PM.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Chief Administrator stated that
Youth A and Youth B were at the house without staff on 11/1/24
for a short time. On 12/6/24 Chief Administrator reported they did
not have video footage to verify the length of time the youth were
alone, as there was a power outage in the neighborhood that
afternoon. The power came on shortly after Staff 2 arrived at the
house.
9

Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 stated that Youth A and Youth B
arrived at the facility after school on 11/1/24 and found that no
staff were present. Another youth had to be taken to the
emergency room by staff, which was why they were not at the
facility. Staff 2 had been called to cover and was on her way when
Youth A and Youth B arrived. During that time, Youth A called the
police and made a report. The police arrived at the house at the
same time as Staff 2. Staff 2 reported the youth were alone no
longer than 15 minutes. Staff 2 recalled the power was out in the
neighborhood that afternoon, but it came back on within 30
minutes of her arrival at the facility.
Documents reviewed:
Sufficiency of Staff/Staff Ratio policy- The policy stated the staff to
consumer ratio is 1 staff for every 3 youth. “Youth Specialists
supervises, directs and provides basic care, security, safety and
welfare to residents. The organization requires that youth
specialist’s ratios are never lower than one staff member to three
youth.”
Analysis Based on interviews with youth and staff, a violation was found.
Interviews determined the two youth were alone somewhere
between 15 and 90 minutes. Regardless of the length of time staff
were not present, a violation was found as staff are required to be
present to supervise youth at all times.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Over the summer staff failed to pick up youth's medication. Youth
was without medication for two weeks.
Investigation On 11/18/24 Complainant 2 reported that Youth A did not receive
her medications for two weeks over the summer, as staff did not
pick the prescriptions up from the pharmacy. Youth A reportedly
had a manic episode as a result of missing her medication.
10

Foster Care Worker was contacted via email on 11/19/24. FCW
reported she was unaware of Youth A’s prescriptions not being
filled over the summer. FCW did not have any knowledge or
documentation of Youth A having a manic episode. On 12/13/24
FCW reported that the only missed medication she was aware of
was one incident where the psychiatrist was out due to an
emergency, delaying the prescription refill. FCW did not provide a
date or name of medication.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Youth A reported there was a two-week
period over the summer where all of her medications were out.
Staff 2 told her that they could not get the prescriptions filled until
a consent form was signed, and they were waiting for DHHS.
Youth A stated she was unsure what medications she was
supposed to be taking at the time. Youth A did not believe there
were any new medications, therefore a new consent form likely
was not needed. Youth A did not report any manic episodes or
increased mental health concerns as a result of missing the
medication.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B and Youth C did
not have any knowledge of Youth A’s medications. Youth B and
Youth C did not report any instances that they did not receive their
medications.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported that Youth A was out of her
medications “a lot” over the summer. Staff 1 indicated that
medications would be empty for weeks at a time. Some days
Youth A had some pills to take, but not all of the ones prescribed.
Staff 1 stated she informed Staff 2 when medications were out,
but Staff 2 did not always get them filled.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face on 11/20/24 in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported there was a time over the
summer that Youth A did not have Trazadone filled, due to her
doctor forgetting to write the prescription. Staff 2 called the
doctor’s office, and they sent the prescription to the pharmacy. It
took about a week for the prescription to be filled. In addition,
Adderall was out intermittently due the pharmacy having a delay in
getting their shipments. Staff 2 stated that Youth A was out of a
few medications over the summer, although she could not
remember any other details about which medications, how long
they were out, or why.
11

Chief Administrator was contacted via email on 12/6/24,
12/10/24 and 1/2/25 for additional information regarding Youth A’s
medications. Chief Administrator provided a copy of Youth A’s
medication logs from Summer 2024. When asked for clarification
about missing medications, Chief Administrator reported the
following: Hydroxyzine is a PRN and not given daily; only given as
needed. Methylphenidate was refused by youth for nine days.
Fluoxetine was out of refills and staff had to wait for a new
prescription. Methylphenidate, Magnesium, Lamotrigine and
Lithium ran out in the middle of the month and were not re-
prescribed; adjusted by the psychiatrist. Prazosin was out of refills
and staff had to wait for a new prescription. Caplyta could not be
filled due to an insurance issue and youth refused the medication.
Adderall dosage changed from 20mg to 30mg; youth refused
medication.
Chief Administrator acknowledged that staff did not write “R” for
refusal on the medication logs. Chief Administrator has spoken
with staff to express the importance of documenting medication
correctly.
Documents reviewed:
Medication logs for Youth A indicated the following missing doses:
• June 2024
o Several days of Hydroxyzine (for anxiety) not given.
o Nine days of Methylphenidate (for ADHD) not given.
• July 2024
o 13 days of Fluoxetine (for depression) missing. She
took it until the 6/11/24 then stopped. The form
indicated “waiting on medication adjustment”, but
then started back on the same dosage on the
6/25/24.
o Methylphenidate, Magnesium, Lamotrigine (for bi-
polar/depression), Lithium (for bi-polar/depression)
all discontinued in the middle of the month.
o Prazosin (for mood disorder) stopped 7/12/24,
indicated “waiting for medication adjustment”, but
then started back on same dosage 7/21/24.
• August 2024
o Missed 6 days of Caplyta (for bi-polar disorder),
received 1 day, then missed 19 days. Form indicated
"delay due to insurance".
o Missed 6 days of Adderall (for ADHD), received it 1
day, then "discontinued- dosage change"
12

Medication policy review:
• The agency’s medication policy dated 5/9/2011 was
reviewed. The policy indicates that staff are to contact the
designated person when a youth reaches 7 days worth of
medication remaining. The policy states, “it is staff’s
responsibility to make sure there is enough medication to
administer at the specified times.” In addition, the policy
states that if a client refuses to take medication an incident
report must be completed.
Analysis A violation was found based on staff and youth interviews and
documentation on the medication log that showed Youth A missed
several days of medication over the summer.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Agency staff need to clearly document any medication refusals
and any medication refill delays, or changes to prescriptions.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
